TRpaWG8b8PzeOXxl6fBb3g.text: One of the most expensive places in all of London town. It truly is lovely to spend a moment here-because truth be told a moment is probably all you will get. It is quite unwelcoming and the peple around try to make a point and make you feel out of place. Especially if you no boat moored on the dock. I would give this a miss unless you are planning on spending a lot of hard cash!

f3W5yiq4UkmiP4br95C-mA.text: Ping Pong has a eat all you can offer called the Lazy Sumday fo £17.50 per person. It is quite a good deal if you are looking to pig out on a Sunday afternoon. This one in St Katherine's Dock offers alfresco seating, much better to sit outside than inside it can get a bit inside during busy times. It has been a great experience when I last went for Lazy Sumday; seating outside by the water, great views of all the boats / yachts sunny day, great weather. And the food is good. It have got some salads, and vegetable dishes which are not available in usual Chinese restaurant hence a plus point for vege lovers! We spent about £50 including drinks for two overall great value (only during Lazy Sumday though).

Hphxi3JgOOJ8Wm16_6LDCg.text: This is such a gorgeous little oasis in amongst all the giant newspaper office blocks of Wapping. When the sun is shining it's lovely to sit out on the port or at one of the quaint little cafes (and a Starbucks) eating lunch and reading a book. They have a few shops there as well, and the place is just generally really well kept and attractive.

aaW-hwFuD-MmJtI0UHhDCg.text: Lovely secluded docks near Tower Bridge. Go and envy all the people who own big expensive boats! There are lots of places to eat and drink around the docks and pubs and restaurants in Wapping are only a short stroll away. Why not combine a visit with a trip to the Tower of London?

ZJYmJnD96gYNxYcSDsvPwQ.text: The food was good and it was reasonably priced, an excellent dining option for a group of people. However, I was most disappointed by the service; with so many waiters around I expected them to be more attentive, we had to ask 3 different people before we managed to get an extra place setting and a chair, as the largest table only seated 8. Also I had to wait a very long time for my drink to be served, despite ordering the food at the same time. When it did arrive I got a glass with a bead of green tea; there was no hot water with it!!! I had to ask especially for some so I could actually have a drink!!! When attempting to get the bill, I had to ask several different people before one came with the bill and when I wanted to pay, I felt I was ignored and despite asking to pay had to wait a further 10 minutes before someone came over.

pAS5OjFecHZahMd0AoPJjA.text: Although this is probably the best of a bad bunch in St. Katherines docks found the food not very filling, quite expensive and the service was quite slow. On the positive it is a good place to sit overlooking the docks and the dim sum is very good. Probably the best place to eat overlooking the docks with only cafe rouge and strada to compete with. Only worth a visit if your starving in the area and can't walk across tower bridge to a selection of better restaurants.

rqTVFk3CD7LoJIcxXWLmWw.text: Lovely dock with restaurants alongside. It is such a pleasure to sit outside at one of the restaurants on a sunny day taking in the atmosphere. This is also close to Tower of London, being on the other side of Tower Bridge. If you are looking for a supermarket there is a Waitrose beyond the dock. It is worth a walk here if looking for a nice place to eat if in the area or visiting the Tower of London. You could also take a Thames Clipper here stopping to Tower Pier. I don't think the St Katharines Pier is currently in use.

yu5OuuRug2RooNxOu06weQ.text: This place is great. I have gone with my boyfriend and another friend of mine and we have always been very happy with the service and the food. I actually thought it was a bit pricy, but they have set menus for less than 10 GBP, so it was within any budget really. Best thing: cocktails. Great atmosphere and you can really take anyone to this place, its classy, elegant and they will make you happy. Out of the question - love the food.

baJEENwrD9FGLgfxsrXm0w.text: Looking for a sunny day spot to meander or simply chill out? It would be hard to beat St Katharine Docks: on the river with excellent views of Tower Bridge with moored boats bobbling and sunlight twinkling on the ripples. There's a wealth of pubs and restos nearby (mostly of the meh variety but some good ones can be found) as well as the Tower of London and the continuation of the Thames Path. Photo opportunities abound in this very London-y and fairly central place that seems nevertheless to be removed from the fray of London life.

GOoWwkAJqlZgoRt-TD9tWw.text: After a long day at the London Tower, we were looking forward to a lunch of dumplings.  This is basically a Dim Sum place where you have to place your orders on cards that are on the tables, and then they bring out the items as they are prepared, rather than having trolleys working their way through the restaurant for you to choose off of.  The main disadvantage is you can't see what you are ordering is going to look like.  To our disappointment, many of the steamed dumplings were over steamed to be point of disintegrating before you could get your chopsticks around them.  Some were OK, but this place is pretty expensive.  Perhaps it is really only possible to get it right in a China town.  We should have been tipped off by the fact that there were no Asian faces in the kitchen. The crispy items were generally better than the steamed ones, which were all over-cooked to the point where the textures were ruined. We spent £15  (~$20) per person and weren't really full at the end.  They did offer an all you can eat option at £23 per person but $30 per person is pretty ridiculous.  We would never spend that much in China town and leave hungry.

rr9qGu_mCxW4pngTmwbMJQ.text: Tasty little parcels of dim sum heaven! For a chain restaurant, I think that a lot of the dishes taste quite authentic. Clay pots, steamed dumplings and spring rolls are just a few of the tasty dishes on this vast menu. There a few vegetarian dishes but not a lot which is why I have not given this a better rating. There are a choice of 3 set menus that have a variety of food which is well worth money.Why not compliment the dishes with a jug of hot sake. There is nothing like an alcoholic drink made from vegetables. ha ha. I think that the self order slip makes the whole experience a lot of better as you can't really complain to the waiter for messing up your order. You can also keep a track of what you have ordered and what left there is to try. The average number of dim sum orders would 3-4 per person. If your feeling greedy or just cant help yourself to try everything, go ahead, as you can take away what you don't finish.This branch is set on a quiet strip of restaurants right on St. Katherine's Dock with fantastic views of Tower Bridge. The restaurant is a lot smaller than other branches but cosy and intimate - so a great place to dine for an important business meeting. New items are added to the menu all the time and I always try them. If you do feel like wetting your taste buds with dim sum, Ping Pong is definitely the way to do it!

IXKgs4xDxoB-JDcvw1AxfQ.text: Very cute area to walk around and see the sights. Beautiful boats, coffee, river views. What's not to like?

z_aaePHXYmvJOxKn1_fnew.text: I should have been a sailor. Popeye, Captain Jack Sparrow, One-eyed Willy (think The Goonies) - I'd be down with their rum drinking, treasure plundering and women chasing. Okay maybe just the rum drinking but still I think there is a sailor in me, which is why I like this place so much.I actually came down here to dream about a houseboat I want to buy but when I arrived I was totally surprised to see it was full of beautiful boats with a  few bustling bars close by. It was like we'd left London for a second. Anyway the boats are beautiful, expensive and there for you to gawp at. I can imagine that it's a lovely place to wander around on a sunny day, or even sit and read a good book.Don't just walk by this London gem, have a look!

SFKv_0fbeMFqFy0d2vw1jw.text: For my first time in London I went to St Katharine's Docks, just to visit on the evening. I needed to eat (obviously) so I chose Ping Pong since I had never tried Dim Sum before.I think the concept of eating 4 or 5 small meals is a great idea. Sometimes you just cannot decide whether you would like a soup or something more "meaty". Dim Sum allows you to pick up a lot of different flavors and textures.In the end I would say the price is alright for the quality and the quantity. I had 4 meals, a big bottle of Tiger beer and it cost me £25. Which is far from overpriced, if you consider the fact that I felt perfectly satiated. It's just that I was not that impressed by the flavors. It was OK but not breathtaking. I always expect a restaurant to give me very high quality products with very strong flavors and character so my rating might sound a little bit severe. I would recommend this place if you need to be sure there's great chance you and your family/friends are gonna like it for sure (no big suprises, food is correct) but I can't say it blew my mind.

biAbaw0Z89MgeioBaYduIw.text: The ambiance is nice and the food decent, but the prices are rather higher than they ought to be.

vw8r_fYmPMQePC0tovQsOA.text: This place is busy busy.  The first time I came here I saw Shilpa Shetty - which surprised me since while the décor is sleek and minimal, the vibe isn't exactly posh.  But then our dim sum parcels came, and I understood why a minor celeb would bother - these little morsels are really good... exactly the sort of thing that appeals to just about anyone on a regular night out.My best recommendation in coming here is to order a wide variety of things... it's dim sum - so go crazy!  The best way to do it is to go with a couple of people and get a ton of things to share - that's the only true way to have the full experience.  Each individual item is well-priced, but it can add up quickly!  The egg rolls here aren't really the best... but the dumplings are tasty and I've heard the squid is good... and one of my friends always insists on this rice and teriyaki chicken thing that comes roasted in a banana leaf.They've got a great list of tasty-sounding cocktails - tons to choose from... (I swear, all the Asian restaurants seem to get that part right!) And they also have lovely non-alcoholic options ... virgin mocktails... and milder things like a beautiful flowering jasmine tea.I've had airheady service here, but again, who's really paying that much attention?  Ping Pong really is all about the food.

Eba5VC7cUKZ59tqgV_1ckA.text: This 'dim sum'  place is a fusion of Asian and western tastes. It is not bad considering I am Asian and the mixture of new textures are surprisingly good.

VzHtD86CBN5iSGaMuNbCTA.text: Great location, great food, so-so prices. Nice atmosphere and service was friendly and competent - two colleagues and I went for supper and somehow ended up with 4 different servers -- all good. Food selection was wide and their set menus made for the best value. I would definitely return for more.

0RAu6Kk0lTAv8dhdZgE-1A.text: If you're a fan of Ping Pong Dim Sum, this is the location you want to come to. Right on St Katherine's Dock, when the sun is shining and it's warm outside, sitting out on their terrace is AMAZING.The staff is particularly helpful and attentive at this location, and while the inside doesn't exactly WOW like the terrace does, it's still worth a visit. The food is delicious, the cocktails are amazing, and the view is, well, pretty priceless after a long winter of grey, rain, and freezing temperatures.

8d4I6EGLUOXvp3CJsziAtA.text: The food was good, cooked fresh, good portions for small bites. They have special allergey friendly menus that cater to top 8 food allergens. Easy to read and navigate through. Atmosphere is very modern and right on the wharf.

cBOQE6pmt_mA0U-igZRNkA.text: Excellent Dim Sum! This place is absolutely the best I've had, including when I travelled in China.

S6Ytw4g1LlHzvNyUpfbKng.text: My parents used to take me to St Katherine's Dock all the time when I was little, but I went recently and it was totally disappointing.A good place to go if you like looking at expensive yachts, barges and the occasional medium-sized ship, but there isn't really anything else of any interest (apart from a sailing rope shop which is quite cool)They restored the original, historical buildings in the marina, which are impressive to look at, but filled them up with rubbish themed Tudor banquet restaurants and naf traditional English pubs. They have beefeaters walking around- enough said.

F5baCfFLlO_QbX5CQ1SL3g.text: Yes, the cocktail menu is excellent.  And it is a fun place for a meal.  The service was OK--nothing too good or too bad.  My problem was the food--I just found it to be all a bit bland.  And we ended up with so many dumpling-like dishes or rice--the food got a bit redundant after a while.

sWklv6DK6-qhv05Rof1GwA.text: This is one of the branchs that Ping Pong has in London. The menus change regularly (they have just released the new Summer menu). The food consist of Dim Sum mainly (small dishes usually steamed of fried).I have ordered here one of the set menus and it had a good range of food, perhaps not a lot of quantity but it was tasty.I have to say that I prefer for dim sum the 'Silk and Spice' Yum cha restaurant located in Chalk Farm that I have also reviewed as I found the food much more authentic and with better prices. But if you are near to Tower Bridge and fancy some dim sum Ping Pong is a good option.

9s8p2mARKO-4REJHyk4jig.text: This is the place to go to for dim sum lovers. It is easy food that goes along very well with the cocktails they serve or with the tea (flower tea as my friends call it).It is a very nice venue for a date in a quiet location and the music is good. It gets quite busy at the week end and at lunch time but works very well for a quiet week day dinner.The food is of good quality and the prices stay affordable if your not too heavy on the cocktails.The staff is friendly and helpful although veggies should always check their plate in the first place.Check out the tables outside as well, they are by the water and nice to enjoy the sight and the sunny weather.

31sd0iAQFSlF7fbrbGNRdQ.text: I have to absolutely agree with Jujwaller - St Katherine's Dock is a hiding place for the busy bustling streets of London. I have been a complete passionate docks goer for the last 10 years after coming across it completely accidentally one afternoon when taking my Italian friends out for a bite. St Katherine's Dock is a marina for boats, fishing boats and luxury yachts. It is quite small and condensed, but is very pretty with penthouse apartments surrounding it and great bars and cafes around the wooden hanging bridges. I am now addicted to my summer Sunday reading afternoons, I pick up my usual from the little cafe and lay on the stone benches by the marina reading a easy going novel. It's absolutely gorgeous, especially summer nights when people are just hanging around on their boats, by the marina, drinking wine and just looking chillled.. It feels like I am a miles away from the bustling noisy capital.. I would definitely recommend the Indian restaurant Mala and the Dickens Inn (fish n'chips) and the Japanese restaurant at the far end of the harbour. Zizzi's and Cafe Rouge are the more usual hangouts for locals. I almost forgot to mention the medieval banquet on the corner of the harbour in Ivory House as well - I am not sure how much this costs nowadays but it is great fun again you can book these through the internet and get a much better discount.. In case of urgent need for a toilet - you could use the Tower Hotel adjacent to the harbour or there are some public toilets at the far end of the harbour on the corner near to the Starbucks - they are usually quite clean! So if you just want to get away from London for a bit - then remember St Katherines Dock is the place to visit!

Mv_gWZU3Kkq_Q7nU0oFvlw.text: St Katharine Docks is a great place to visit just to enjoy the boats and the happy , easy-going feel of the place . There are shops here , none of them are to my taste  but that doesn't stop me from walking around here on a fairly regular basis . Its reeks of money , but it never feels unwelcoming to those of us who don't have piles of cash .

bA726M4zD5zkwkJhJQXl9g.text: Okay-- I know this is a chain, but it was super close to our hotel (The Tower Hotel), so we ended up here. Twice. The second time being we were so impressed. My travel companions are the pickiest of eaters. This place is amazing for that because there are SO MANY CHOICES. I love tapas, and tasting menus, so I love the dim sum concept because I can try so many different things. My boyfriend adored it the first time, and insisted on coming back. We sat out in the cold just so we could eat here again lol. (We ordered multiples of the asparagus!)I want to mention that the first time I came here, it was just my boyfriend and I, sitting by another couple that appeared to be on a date. The girl couldn't seem to find a wine she liked, so our amazing waiter offered to go next door to another restaurant to get a wine she would like. How is that for service? I was so impressed!Now I just have to find a comparable dim dum place in Philly!

ourlVfi1RTDd6pkOiqeovg.text: The docks themselves are lovely - it's a really excellent oasis of calm in an otherwise pretty busy part of town.  They're easy to get to and surrounded by quite a few pubs and eateries, with a Waitrose just a few minutes away. Downsides:The decking can be incredibly slippery when it's frosty.  Parts of the decking are rough and you have firm footing but other parts are just smooth wood which is what creates a slippery surface.  If you slip you're straight in the water which must be pretty vile.The shower/toilet facility leaves much to be desired.  It's freezing as the fan heaters don't seem to do much more than blow out cold air, and the showers are the joyful combination of poor water pressure, never getting very hot, and going quite cold after about 5 minutes.I don't have much dock experience to compare St Katharine's to, but it seemed on the "meh" side of A-OK to me.

bV9bvTxgBhvFe3yLnWqKqA.text: Easily one of my favourite restaurants in London. The ambience at this particular Ping Pong by St Katharine's Dock is immaculate. The food is delectable. The Sunday all you can eat for 20 pounds is the best value for money Sunday Brunch in London. Amazing food at all the Ping Pong's in London.

HXjv2Gv_RfVmXgDbod2FHQ.text: So, this place isn't cool because it's a dock with nice boats, it's cool because it's a dock with nice boats hidden in London. If you walk along the pier of San Francisco or Portugal, you can see lots of yachts, but the fact that London isn't a coastal city, and these docks are right downtown, well, that's something to enjoy.Definitely recommend taking a stroll here, but don't make it your first stop if you are showing tourist friends around. I'd say make it one of your last stops, since they need to see and feel London, to appreciate the docks.

RT5PifcJZdhrUYqaF5HTXQ.text: I do love this place. I worked for ten years round the corner, so I watched as it was built up and the restuarants and bars moved in. It can get absolutely packed in the summer evenings at the end of the week - the crowd is mostly business/suits as it's a bit out of the way for tourists (even being just over the road from the tower!) My favourite places: Mala - best (and only!) Indian - really nice food, great service. Dickens Inn - go upstairs for pizza and sit on the balcony looking out over the boats. Ping Pong - often ignored, but actually very very good. usually the last restaurant to fill up.Cote - very reasonable and good quality. Go for a walk around the whole complex and you could do one course each at three/four different places! Definitely finish up at Cafe Rouge for pudding! Also, visit at night - it's stunningly pretty with all the lights on the trees and the boats.

CiCsucCg8GhVsa9pm7FkdA.text: The first time I found St Katherine's Docks was purely by chance. We were walking around the Tower of London late on a Sunday evening. Having just finished the very last episode of The Tudors, we wanted to let the show live on by walking around the centrepiece of the show. As we walked under the Tower Bridge arches, not quite ready to head home, I saw a sign for the Docks in a little corner of the buildings. I convinced my partner to check it out with me, and we were amazed!The docks are now one of my favourite spots to walk around. With the exception of that hideous-looking hotel that overtakes the view of the bridge, the Docks are great to grab a coffee, sit down for dinner or walk around.

p8EtYTq4aV3Vi5bnXwLo2A.text: The food market every Friday is AMAZING.Really good quality food, which can be enjoyed in the lovely scenic docks.It has everything from Fish and Chips (great quality, not too greasy) to paella, Ethiopian (my personal favorite), Jamaican, Haggis, pork pies and the BIGGEST cookies I have ever seen.Generally 6 quid will get you a good meal, and the quality tends to be very good street food. Perfect to spend a summer lunch: we migrate to their from our office almost every Friday!

ErGd-uhHGRh8aulzkZ67eQ.text: Great service, wonderful food, and fair prices. I recoment the blossoming teas. The waitstaff was fast and friendly. If you are in London this place is a must for good dim sum.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom. The jasmine flower tower tea.

VJ_LWurDUnr9qzMIHL1NSA.text: Ping Pong offers pretty good dim sum and other Chinese-inspired cuisine at an affordable price (especially for Central London). The set menus and cocktails are great and St. Katharine's Dock is a wonderfully quiet place to an enjoy an afternoon. The main problem with this Ping Pong location is that the staff are not especially interested in customers. They take their time chatting amongst themselves before seating your or taking your order and all but disappear once the food arrives. Though the food is good, the poor level of service ruins the dining experience.

BNg2O_aqH0ygExvXm42qfA.text: The Lazy Sumdays deal is very good if you love dim sum and can eat a lot of it!  Which I totally can.  Some favourites were Crispy Prawn Ball, King Prawn and Scallop sticky rice, prawn and chive dumplings and their char siu buns.  The har gau is pretty good but the not best that I have ever had.The service here was great.  Our waitress was really polite, kind and attentive.  What more could you want?  Also the location is lovely, overlooking St. Katherine's Dock.  Super lovely!

jqDAbJSqgrBQE6gfj2iSng.text: I'm a huge fan of the two Ping Pong restaurants in DC, so I had high hopes for this one in spite of the bad Yelp reviews. Welp, should have heeded Yelp. The service was really friendly but the food was quite sub-par. The pork puff has always been my favorite at the US outlets but this version tasted as if it had been frozen and reheated- a real disappointment. The dumplings were nothing special and the chicken wings were small and not very flavorful. We ended up spending £50 for food for two people (no beverages) and although we were super full afterwards, the quality of the food was just not worth the money.

yb71cmJPo-7mf8DrQUz9PA.text: Went yesterday for a birthday treat - unlimited dimsum for £22.95. It didn't disappoint! Had lovely time, they were very accommodating of our party and put up with 3 small children too. Would recommend the lazy dimsumday, meant we tried everything and didn't hold back! Spent about 3 hours there. Great cocktails. Will go again. Waiter was very busy but still had time for our faffing on!

9Zw-QpYXpMBw-qJLxa_d0g.text: The four of us got a Super 8, which consisted of 5 different dim sum pieces, chicken on rice bowl, soup and hot tea for each of us.   A fabulous meal for only 8 pounds each.  The soup was some of the best I have ever had.

REO4sybjEkdysYsDeZTFsQ.text: Expensive and not as good as those in China Town. If you're desperate for dim sum and can't be bothered to go to China Town then you're like me has to settle for this around here. To be honest, the frozen dim sum you can get in Chinese supermarkets are better than at Ping Pong and they're much cheaper.

nSK3yEyg7PDlVD_8qCvZ3w.text: I very much adore this destination in the capital, and generally I don't talk about it with people who don't already know it exists, simply because it's MY secret haven within MY vivacious city and I don't want the likes of you spoiling it.However because I'm nice...To being, learn the lingo and look like a pro. Most will say, 'St. Katharine's Dock' but her true name is 'St. Katharine Docks.' See the difference? St. Katharine is her name with no claim or ownership to the docks themselves, unlike Henry's poor wife Kathryn H whom I believe very much did make her docks her own and wore them as her final accessory, I might add.Also, don't look like a numbty by doing your 'How to ind it" research before you get there. If you've never been or haven't been in a while, it's easy to forget where it is. Take your significant other by the hand and walk them out of Tower Hill station, past the old city wall, down the underpass and burst out at the docks! What a legend! I can hear the brownie point tinkling in like a winning fruit machine in Vegas! Don't on the other hand, select this as a romantic meeting place for a first date if 1, your date has never been there before and 2, the London Olympic marathon happens to be running right past it, so all the surrounding roads are blocked off and a rather elaborate detour is in place, causing your perspective new beau to be 43 minutes late!

VGnDZRCReezUJ1n-RcgxiQ.text: What a find.  Was walking around after a long day and stumbled upon Ping Pong. Excellent from start to finish:  chicken and cashew nut dumpling, spicy veg dumpling, mushroom, veg, black bean rice pot, and potato edamame cake. Not in London often but will return!

P_y3cRp92OqYPbGI0Ebe6A.text: I was missing London today, so I will indulge and write my memories of this lovely area!  How I have missed it, for as many times as I have been to the Tower, is beyond me, but I did, until a team retreat to London where I was asked to be in charge of the logistics... including food (thanks to Yelp!).  If the boss is going to make us be together and do work things all weekend, I'm at least going to enjoy my meals on the company dime!  So we spent the morning at the Tower then we walked to St Katharine Docks.  How lovely!  And what a surprise!  I kind of felt like I was in another city.  It is beautiful!  Work BFF and I looked at each other and both said, "Super cute!"  Clearly we have been missing out... of course after that I ended up here a lot... including one of those awful, awkward dates from an online dating website.  At least the setting was lovely, almost makes you forget how much awkward is happening.We ate at one of the restaurants over looking the docks (Ping Pong), although clearly even my British colleagues had trouble finding the place as a few of us were sitting there waiting for some time, wondering if they were lost... in the Tower (cue evil cackle).  Eventually they all found it.  And of course there were very polite, "Oh, this is splendid" or "Lovely indeed" comments... which, knowing them, I can translate to, "Super cute!"  As far as driving there, good luck, but walking there is a cinch and you should definitely make your friends go for drinks or dinner here.  Or if your boss is mandating that you spend a weekend with the co-workers, that you already spend 24 hours a day with, take over and book a lunch here... or you can use it to retreat from them ;)  Either way, you won't regret it.

vwW68Ygp96BRSJlx0HxkHw.text: The area:   astonishing views of water, boats, tower bridge;  a marina within a city.    Will make you question what London is. The experience:  peaceful, calm, safe, intriguing, tasteful.  When the sun sets, the water turns red, when it's dark, the walkways light up and you feel like you're on some dock of centuries past.  Little bridges take you across the three separate water basins.  Plenty of camera opportunities, whether it's sunny, overcast, dark or wet.   Good for:   picnics when it's 'warm', sitting on a bench and making out, taking a little walking tour with your parents, going for a coffee Saturday afternoon.The Bad:  most establishment are chains:  in the entrance area by the bridge:  Ping Pong, Cafe Rouge, and about four other chains.  It's terribly sad and unfortunate, but it's a London problem, not a local one.  Subtract one star for that.As a NYC transplant, I have to request that we all stage an uprising against any chain restaurants / coffee establishments, and then boycott them.     Happy yachting, comrades.Just leave the Waitrose (across the street on the Thomas More St. entrance to the Docks) alone.

rVXVs1RhbrIpmqyVD06Kow.text: St Katharine's Docks would get their 5th star if the chain venues were replaced with independent places instead. Gorgeous surroundings and a peaceful spot right next to one of the busiest parts of town. If you're a tourist this place is definitely worth a visit :)

W4xDMF8Nz0az0ECYdSmo0g.text: A beautiful relaxing way to spend a weekend afternoon. Some nice boats to look at, sensible restaurants including a quite interesting Starbucks pavilion. It feels strange to find a place like this in the middle of London, it's secluded location perfecting keeping the place away from the majority of tourists. Come by at dusk or night for some stunning views.

Ckp7DbM-mhaOzQDmMRkPBw.text: Quality of food was excellent and the service was close to perfect. Family lunch where vegans and carnivores are mixed, everyone found their pleasure. Perfect family lunch thanks to the food and service.

RfXVh4Fps_tVIK3hJCDqPQ.text: OK chain of Chinese restaurants serving a variety of slightly overpriced yet tasty dishes. Popular with the younger generation who seem to have large disposable incomes. Slightly odd that noodles were 'off' when we visited on a Friday night but other than that would probably go back again when my next salary comes in!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom

WWmKQSq11D6TXhIV2kNQfg.text: The food was just okay. The table was too small for two people, and your seat is too close to the next table that you can actually hear what are they talking. The food was served fast but then took 30mins for them to bring us a check. We even asked 4 different servers for a check wouldnt recommend it if you are in hurry. The iced tea selection is good though.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom

QGxvBJ6UQjkA8VAXo73M8w.text: Food is not bad, but the service is horrible. I entered the restaurant at 4pm, only a few tables are occupied. As soon as I got seated the server delivered an appetizer to my table. It was my first visit so I guess it's something complimentary as it's even faster than serving water - it turns out to be ordered by some others. When they figured out the mistake, the server didn't say anything and just simply add that to my order for me, pretending nothing happened. I should know because it took them over ten minutes to get a cup of water for me. Very unsatisfied.P.S. when I checked out I complaint about this and they agree to refund me, but I did eat the appetizer so I didn't ask for the refund.

0XWdBWBoASLUCyDxmPnnwg.text: The dim sum was sooooo good. Great options for vegans. The whole experience was great.

2el18cPmcZBp0u_0qtnIbw.text: Ambiance of the dock is nice, food and service were awful. The dim sum tasted reheated and was obviously not made on premises.

d4nYlkucoAXWUSu2jNksHA.text: An interesting to place to visit at least once if you're in London for a long time. Go on a Friday when there's an International Food market.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom. My pasta from the market

snlbOOb1vwc8d2n6ZvD0gw.text: Great fusion Chinese. In London for 4 days and have been here twice. Highly recommend the ribs , firecracker rolls, shui mai crab and shrimp. Nice location overlooking the water. Friendly staff and a decent wine selection.

Lb1R7u9utUmLqjKRtiuDtw.text: This was first time to Ping Pong. It was a really nice day so we could sit outside which was definitely a plus. This is essentially a Asian tapas bar. We ordered various plates. My favourite was the coconut mushroom soup and the pork spring rolls. The best dish was the dessert ..the coconut parfait. Yuuumy! The food was good but I can't say it's the best dim sum I have had. I also found it quite expensive considering the small portions. I am sure I'll come back but definitely not my fav Asian restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom

WECIuuZdJPlWcRW7illU8w.text: Was craving dumplings and decided to check out St. Katherine's Docks.Ping Pong was easy to find near the main restaurant area. Being a late lunch the place was empty. The restaurant was decorated nicely to celebrate Chinese New Year; year of the monkey.Staff were every helpful, asking if I had been to there restaurants before, when I said I hadn't they kindly explained how the ordering works and recommends number of dishes to have per person. I decided to go with go with there Ping Pong Selection set menu, which had a selections for fried and steamed dumplings plus a rice dish. It was heaps of food and satisfied my craving. Food was well presented and each item was explained when delivered. All was delicious, my favourite was the potato and edamame cake. What stole the show was the flowering tea. I was fascinated by the dry tea leaves come to life in the boiling water become a stunning piece of art. Good food, fascinating tea and very attentive service will defiantly go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom

tlUyrbn0Acla_ZBgdEL6PQ.text: I came here by chance a few weeks ago and have since started working nearby. It's a mix of commercial and residential property, with a vast array of shops (mostly food) - with tapas, sush, Italian turkish etc. It's one of the few places which looks good, no matter the weather.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom

JQStEMjxsxOhC27Qvg8_4Q.text: I like Ping Pong.  I've been to three different locations of theirs and each has it own vibe.  This one overlooks the boats of St. Katherine's dock and has a heated outdoor seating area.  I've been here on both a lazy Sunday afternoon and more recently a very late Friday night. Service 3-4 stars: The service did it's best on Friday - but were clearly overwhelmed.  Everyone at every table around me had to ask what had happened to their food after more than a half hour wait.  They knew they were in the weeds though - and provided me a coupon for a free cocktail for my next visit (and they have quite a selection of exotic ones). They also ran out of chili sauce (a staple) that evening. On a lazy Sunday it was much better - even though that's the day they offer unlimited Dim Sum for 22 quid. Can't eat that much - but, many around me were enjoying it.Food: 3-4 stars: Largely depends upon what you get.  I've had the set menu for 1, shared the set menu for 2 and have finally decided what I like and don't like - so, it's a better deal for me to just order a la carte now.  Do recommend the set menu for first-timers.  Here are my favorites: Prawn toast, squid ink seafood dumplings, chive and shrimp dumplings, spicy soup made with coconut milk and brocolli with a yummy sauce and sesame seeds.  Least favorite: any of the rice dishes, the mushroom puff and the chicken dumplings. Atmosphere 3-4: Casual and good for everything from dates to hanging out with friends and family.  Offer an on-going student discount - so always a few of those around.Value: 3-4, again depending on what you like.  While many natives scoff at dim sum served by   a chain - you can count on what you get maybe not being the best dim sum ever - but definitely consistently good.Bottom Line:  When that dim sum craving hits again, I'll go back here to get my fix - but, I'll avoid the busier times.

EJBPuMQ6r5nWrp8Gp87XYg.text: Having never been in this part of London (as a Londoner) I was really pleasantly surprised by this little pocket by the Tower of London. Has a south of France feel (although probably a lot colder!) with the boats docked in the water and the array of restaurants to choose from. I'll definitely be back around here soon - although maybe more in the summer months!

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom

HUDaqvupfeMltCe0bKTBCQ.text: Wandered in for some Dim Sum shortly after touching down in London. Ping Pong had a great selection of food, it all tasted great, and the service was speedy. The restaurant was completely packed by 1PM. They forgot our edamame and didn't serve it until well after we were done eating but were kind enough to take it off the bill.

bL-jcgmKHzZs39ftOxMNNg.text: I popped into the cafe with my parents during one of their visits to London, after stumbling across it during our wander through the docks. I can't comment on its main menu choices, but for a drink and a cake I'd definitely recommend a visit.We'd actually had lunch earlier but skipped dessert, so were specificially looking for sweet treats. I had a chocolate orange tart which was excellent - although, so chocolatey that I had to save half of it for when I got home! I also tried a bit of my Dad's Red Velvet cake which was pretty perfect, and my Mum's carrot cake has an ACTUAL ICING CARROT on top. The slice sizes for the cakes were really impressive, and the service was quick and easy. I'd definitely pay another visit to St Katharine Docks Cafe if I was in the area!

cAemLd3w25e_-9IInZXivA.text: I guess this place is OK when you're too stretched to bother making a trip to China Palace @ Excel or Royal China Club out West. I suppose it's not the worst dim sum in London and it's convenient since Ping Pong is seemingly everywhere these days but the food itself is unimaginative.The decor and service is certainly much more inspired that most Chinese restaurants but the menu is very Westernised. Chicken in dumplings is not too common in China so I find it pretty weird. I understand pork is not as popular in the UK but having it as an option would be nice. Hot dishes, unless steamed, can arrive to the table lukewarm or cold. For the portions, I feel the price is on the higher side as it literally took a mountain of those steaming baskets to stack up on my table before I felt full.Their Sunday deals are very appealing. All you can eat and I think cocktails are somehow involved in the deal but I can't remember exactly how. For that I'm adding the third star. Otherwise this place gets two.

_uE8AibaJKSsI_yHteKCoA.text: Lovely spot to escape the hassle and bustle of the city...  The dock is home to several restaurants and bars making It pleasant and lively to visit at any time of the day.  In summer you can relax on one of the benches soaking up the sun while seeing how the boats enter and exit the dock via the working lock.

photos.caption: Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ping Pong - London, United Kingdom

mIxQakD86ZZBLgXSSxdOdA.text: Nice location on St Katherine's Docks, especially in the summer when you can sit outside. The dishes are all small plates of dim sum, you usually get about 3 dumplings per serving so need to order several dishes per person. They have a standard menu and also seasonal specialities - when we went last week, the special lamb spring rolls were particularly good. Disappointingly, quite a few dishes (including some of the specials) had sold out. The dim sum we ordered were generally good and tasted quite fresh and flavoursome, however for the size of the portions it's a little expensive.

bAWTiFCSwKrZCj2R0MQvUQ.text: I'd been dying to go to ping pong for longest, but just like meeting brad Pitt it just didn't seem to be happening. UNTIL YESTERDAY!!!!the seats were limited so we had to sit near the dumpling steamer section.... Ended up with a free facial.I wasn't ravenous so despite their recommendations of 5 dishes minimum, I picked three.Let's start with the honey glazed chicken wings . Oh My. They were delicious! I never really expect much from chicken wings but honestly they were so good. Sweet sticky and salty. Yum.I tried their scallop and chive steamed dumplings which were so well seasoned I could've cry from pure joy!It's one of those places you spend £20 at but kinda leave with room for more. But the flavours just may make me over look those factors.

QlbS2Uou8ZameQVFdks5yA.text: Awful food! I by accident booked tours around the fact we were going to visit the Borough Market and realized it was closed on Sunday's. I decided to try this spot with my husband because of distance. The ambiance is quiet nice and pleasant servers however the food was just so bland and made with such low quality ingredients. Don't waste your time even bothering to try their food. We ordered the steamed shrimp dumplings and the vegetarian tasting menu. Not one thing has flavor. One of the options in the veggie menu was a tofu rice bowl and it had some broccoli in it that tasted like it was boiled for days. Gross!
